text.content: Click a Lesson or Activity to learn more about What Parents Can Do.
Childproofing is a way to create a safe environment for children to explore their surroundings and learn about the world around them.
Click each caution cone to learn some safety tips for creating a safe environment.

graphic.notes: cutaway illustration of house similar to that found at http://www.cpsc.gov/cpscpub/pubs/252.pdf

audio.transcript: Some parents worry that if they childproof their home, other parents will think they are being overprotective. Instead, parents should look at childproofing as a way to create a safe environment for their children to explore their surroundings and learn about the world around them. Click each caution cone to learn some safety tips for creating a safe environment by minimizing the risks posed by different unsafe situations and objects in the home.

text.content:
Cabinets and Drawers

Cabinets and drawers often contain sharp objects, chemicals, medications, and items that could pose a choking hazard.

Whenever possible, parents should install latches on all drawers and cabinets in all rooms. If they have an irregular cabinet and can't find a latch that fits, parents might consider emptying the cabinet or making it a spot for toys and other safe objects.

Parents should also keep poisons and chemicals completely locked away and out of a baby's reach.

Tables and Fireplaces

Tables and fireplace hearths have sharp corners. Coffee tables are especially hazardous because as babies learn to walk, they use these low tables as an aid.

Parents can install table cushions. Some just cover the corners while others completely surround the table. Parents can also make their own padding system or remove dangerous furniture until their child is older.

Stairways

More than half of all nonfatal injuries to children are from falls. Many of these falls involve unprotected stairways.

Parents can install safety gates at the top and bottom of stairs. For the top of stairs, they should make sure that the gate has a secure latch and is not a pressure-type gate.

Always supervise young children as they learn to climb stairs.

Electrical Outlets

Unprotected electrical outlets cause thousands of injuries each year. Parents can install face plates or outlet covers and make sure power strips are covered with a suitable safety device.

Electrical cords are often attached to heavy equipment or lamps, and babies and toddlers can pull them down onto themselves. Parents should bundle cords and secure the cords to furniture so they cannot be pulled by children. Watch teething babies very carefully, since cords are a tempting treat.

Doors and Windows

Doors pose several hazards. Doors can lead to areas of the home or outdoors that aren't safe for children. They can also pose a finger-pinch hazard.

Parents can cover doorknobs with safety coversâ€”one for each door they don't want their child to be able to open.

Parents should also be aware of cords hanging from blinds. These cords can be a choking hazard to any child. This can be resolved by tying the cords near the top of the window so they are never hanging within a child's reach.

Kitchen Appliances

Toddler hands are just the right height to reach stove burners, pot handles, and even power or gas knobs. Ovens can be opened and crawled into, whether on or off. Dishwashers can be opened and often contain sharp objects such as knives or breakables like glassware.

Parents can install locking latches on all appliances that open and close. Knob covers will prevent a child from turning on burners. Always keep pot handles turned inward while cooking.

Plants

Many plants are poisonous and can cause illness or death. Potting materials also pose a choking hazard.

Parents should be aware of the types of plants they keep. It helps to make sure plants are labeled. Do not use rocks or marbles in potting materials or as a ground cover for plants. Keep poisonous plants well out of reach, preferably outside the home completely.
